section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need toy vehicles, or Connecting Cubes to represent vehicles.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Me and My Cars, we talked about lots of different types of vehicles. Now we are going to make a parade by lining up vehicles!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the vehicle Vocabulary Card to reteach the word. Give each child one vehicle.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will each add a vehicle to the line to make a parade, and tell how many vehicles are in line in all.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Put down one car to start the parade and announce that the parade has one vehicle. Add one more. Count the vehicles aloud and say that there are two vehicles in all. Remind children that the last number you count is how many vehicles there are in all.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How many vehicles are in the parade? Can you add your vehicle to the parade? Now how many vehicles are in the parade in all?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue the activity until each child has had a chance to add at least one vehicle to the parade, and there are 10 vehicles total.

Talk About Counting Ask children how they know how many vehicles there are in all. Encourage children to notice that the last number said is the number of cars in all. Discuss how each time a car is added, the total goes up by one. Point out that each successive number when counting represents a total that is one more.
Encourage children to touch each vehicle as they count. They can also move each vehicle as they are counted to ensure they count every vehicle exactly once.
As children add vehicles to the parade line, have them predict how many there will be when one more is added. Compare their predictions with a total counted.
Use Number Cards to review the words for numbers one through ten. Encourage children to count in their home language. Then, help them count in English.
To increase fine motor skills, have children “drive” their vehicles across the table to their place in line. Encourage them to add the vehicle neatly and quietly to the end of the parade line.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Me and My Cars, we talked about the different ways we could sort the vehicles in the book.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary We also learned the words sort and vehicle.
Use the sort and vehicle Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will sort pictures of vehicles in different ways.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Show children the Activity Cards and use the prompts on the back to discuss the pictures. Then place the Activity Cards face-up in front of the children.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s sort these vehicles by number of wheels. We will count the number of wheels, and put vehicles with the same number of wheels in the same group.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Help children count the wheels on each picture and then sort the cards by number of wheels. Point out that most vehicles have the same number of tires on the side you can see as on the side you can’t see.
Repeat Have children sort another way, such as by color or use.
Extend Have children choose a new attribute to sort by. Any attribute is fine as long as the cards can be separated into clear groups.
Talk About Classifying Ask children to share the ways they sorted the vehicles. How did they decide which group to put each vehicle into? How are these groups the same? How are they different?

Designate only two categories for sorting the cards, such as helping vehicles and not. Guide children to decide which pile it belongs in by asking whether or not the vehicle belongs in the category. For example: Is the fire engine a helping vehicle? Yes or no?

Have children sort individually using half of the cards. Make sure each child has a chance to sort the cards. Encourage children to sort by different attributes such as color, use, or number of wheels, so that multiple children do not sort the cards in the same way.

For children who need language support, review each vehicle picture by naming it and pointing to that vehicle in the book. Have children repeat the vehicle names aloud. Talk about what each vehicle is used for.

This sorting activity has many opportunities for vocabulary development, specifically: color words, number words, and vehicle names. The picture cards can be used in conjunction with the vocabulary cards for additional examples of some of these vehicles.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need the Day 2 Activity Cards.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Me and My Cars we talked about the different vehicles and how they help us. Now we’re going to talk about where these vehicles are using location words.
In this activity, we are going to practice our location words. I will ask you to place these cards above, under, next to, near, or far from each other. You will follow my directions to move the card.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Start Place the Activity Cards in a line on the table. Ask, What is next to the fire truck? Guide children to point to and say the name of the vehicle (or vehicles) that is next to the fire truck card.

Place Vehicles Ask a child to place a vehicle using a location word. For example, Place the bike above the car. Guide the child to move the card into position. Repeat using various vehicles and location words (over, under, above, on, beside, next to, between, in front of, near, far, etc.) until all children have had multiple turns to place vehicles.

Make Your Own Placement Give each child a set of two cards. Invite children to make their own vehicle placements. Encourage children to use any of the location words they know to describe where they have placed their vehicle.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How did you know where to put the vehicle? What words tell you its location?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Start with a smaller set of location words, such as near, far, and next to. Repeat the activity using only these words until children are confident. Then add new location words one at a time.
Instead of naming a vehicle, describe it using an attribute: Put the vehicle with two wheels above the vehicle a farmer might use. Include the location words left and right as children are ready.
For children who may need more language support, review the location words and have children act them out. Also, review each picture and name the vehicle. Have children repeat the names aloud.
Encourage children to stand up on their tip toes or crouch down on the ground as they place their cards where you have directed. You may also have children act out the way their vehicle moves.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need about 20 Pattern Blocks for each child. Each child should have a mix of various shapes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Wheels on the Bus we talked about what shapes we see in vehicles and discussed which Pattern Blocks we could use to make some vehicles.
You will build a vehicle using Pattern Blocks. I will use location words to tell you where each type of block should go.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: First Step Give each child a pile of Pattern Blocks. Let’s start with one hexagon. Find a hexagon and move it far from the pile. You’ll need a lot of space to build! Guide children to find one hexagon and pull it far from the pile. Now, put another hexagon next to it. These will be our wheels!

Build Guide children to build a vehicle step-by-step, directing them to place Pattern Blocks using location words. For example: Place four squares above the wheels. These are the body of our car! Place one triangle on top of the squares. That will be our window. Now, put three diamonds in front of the car as our road.

Build Your Own After children have finished following your directions to build a vehicle, encourage children to build their own vehicles however they would like. Ask each child to describe where they chose to place at least one Pattern Block.

Talk About Following Directions Celebrate the many creative vehicles children have made. Then, discuss what it was like to follow directions. What was difficult about following my directions? How else could you make pictures of vehicles using Pattern Blocks?

Limit the location words you use to next to, above, and under. Also, use colors in addition to shape names as you give directions. For example, when asking for a hexagon, refer to it as a yellow hexagon.

Give children two-step directions as they build: Place two hexagons next to each other, and one square above them. Encourage children to describe where they have placed their pattern blocks using location words.

Review shape and location words before starting the activity, as well as key vocabulary such as vehicle and wheels. Pair hand motions with each location word you use, such as spreading your hands out wide for far and holding them palm-to-palm for next to.

Create a separate working space for each child using manila folders as partitions. Decreasing distractions will increase children’s focus on creating their own vehicles. When children are done building, take down the partitions and celebrate the surprise of seeing the vehicles everyone has created!
